newsitem.title: USA: BP, union agree terms on Ohio plant closure.
newsitem.headline: BP, union agree terms on Ohio plant closure.

text.p: BP Oil, a U.S. unit of the British Petroleum Co plc, said Wednesday that the union representing workers at its Lima, Ohio refinery have agreed to terms for closing the plant.

The union ratified late Tuesday an agreement that includes severance pay equivalent to two weeks for each year of service, with a minimum of 12 weeks and a maximum of 52 weeks, BP said in a statement Wednesday.
The company wouldn't say how much the package for the 270 union-represented workers would cost.

"This is a good agreement for all parties," said Don Kuenzli, BP Lima plant manager, in the statement. He termed the agreement, which also allows for a bonus of up to 20 percent of annual pay for meeting safety, environmental and reliability targets, as "unprecedented in the oil industry."
BP announced last November that it was not able to find a buyer for the plant, which it put up for sale in January, 1996 as part of a worldwide restructuring.
The Lima unit has capacity to process 161,500 barrels of crude oil a day and is the largest of Ohio's four oil refineries.

BP said last year that it will keep a neighboring chemicals plant open and it is studying various options for some limited use of the site. The only option made public is a plan to turn the site into a distribution terminal.
However, if the terminal option is pursued most of the 475 union and non-union staff associated with the refinery are expected to lose their jobs.
